150576155.review:
Batman: Arkham Asylum, though my attempt to revisit it on PC was thwarted by technical issues, remains an undisputed classic from the Xbox 360 era. This game, a beacon of excellence in the superhero gaming landscape, seamlessly combines a gripping narrative with innovative gameplay that redefined what it meant to be the Dark Knight.

From the moment you step into the menacing halls of Arkham Asylum, the game immerses you in a dark and atmospheric world. The narrative, steeped in Batman lore, unfolds with cinematic flair, introducing iconic characters and unraveling a story that captures the essence of the Caped Crusader.

The gameplay is a masterclass in superhero mechanics. The fluid combat, intuitive detective work, and strategic stealth elements create a dynamic experience that mirrors the versatility of Batman himself. Arkham Asylum's success in this regard set a new standard for superhero games, influencing the genre for years to come.

While my PC experience was unfortunately marred by crashes, the memories from the Xbox 360 days are filled with admiration for the impeccable design, the engaging puzzles, and the stellar voice acting that brought the characters to life.

For those fortunate enough to experience Batman: Arkham Asylum on PC without technical hurdles, I envy the journey that awaits. This game is a timeless masterpiece that transcends its release era, proving that even in the ever-evolving landscape of gaming, certain titles endure as benchmarks of excellence.

150267894.review:
This is a fantastic game.

Everything from the visuals to the audio to the dialogue are all excellent. The performances of the two leads are fantastic, the story and ambiance are very good, and perhaps most notably, the combat system is a lot of fun.

This game is right up there with the original Gears of War and Resident Evil 4 as one of the most innovative games of the 2000s. It introduces so many clever gameplay mechanics, the combat has depth to it (later emulated in the excellent Sleeping Dogs), and it's just a fun game. The use of gadgets is also pretty fun, although there are so many of them, and some I never used.

You can see just how much effort went into every aspect of Arkham Asylum, with the art design and even with all the character bios and audio tapes. It's just a really impressive game. And the Riddler secrets are actually fun enough that I went through and collected all 240 of them.

I also appreciate the game's length. You can probably power through the story in 12 hours, but it's realistically a 15-20 hour game for most people, which is a good length for this. It doesn't overstay its welcome.

The one major criticism I have is the level design. It looks beautiful (especially for a 14 year old game), but some of the levels are mazes that can be a real pain to traverse, especially after you've finished the story and are going back for the Riddler secrets. Finding all the sealed doors and remembering all the alternate paths to get around the Caves and the Medical Facility can be a real annoyance.

Also, while I enjoy the Detective Mode mechanic, sometimes I felt the game wanted you to use it too much, which caused a FOMO because it masks the game's excellent visuals and art design.

All in all, this game is a classic. I'm giving it a 90%, but I would have given it a 95% if it had not been for the maze-like level design.

Highly recommended.

149960552.review:
It has taken me years to finally finish this game. I had it on XBox 360 and started it a few times before life got in the way and I didn't get to finish it. Last time I tried, I got most of the way through, then got stuck and took a break. When I came back, my save file had been deleted... I couldn't bring myself to start it all over again. 

But having switched to PC and wanting to finally play Arkham Knight, I purchased it here. And now I've finally finished the game. It's so great. The combat is less refined here than it would be in City, and from what I've heard and seen, Knight as well, but it's still incredibly satisfying to beat up some goons or to pick them off one by one from the shadows. There's also a really smooth progression in terms of the complexity of the gameplay, as new gadgets are added, allowing access to new areas and new combinations of moves; and new variables such as snipers and the roaming lunatics keep you on your toes and force you to adapt your play style.

The story is very simple, but it's excellent. Joker gets himself captured by Batman on purpose, and then takes over Arkham Asylum - he also plans to poison Gotham with the Titan formula to create an army. It's a well-paced story that kept me wanting to know what happened next, meaning I found the game quite hard to put down.

The only things I would knock in this game is that it's rather easy, and the ending is a tad anticlimactic. The boss fights are big set pieces in terms of presentation, but the bosses are not too hard to beat. I died once or twice on each one, but didn't struggle too much. Other parts of the game are also fairly easy. I didn't play on hard, mind you. I'll probably do that next. And the Titan Joker fight which ends the game is an example of a fairly easy fight. You fight waves of Joker's goons - a cakewalk by that point - and then pull Joker down with the Batclaw and beat him up a bit. Repeat until done. 

Still, this is a great game, particular for its amazing world design and atmosphere, and for how fun it is to play. Highly recommended.

149946490.review:
[h3] Worthy of the comic book’s legacy, Arkham Asylum is bat to the bone [/h3]

My perception of Batman is built entirely on the gritty, grounded realism of The Dark Knight films. These films captured my imagination as they didn’t require a considerable suspension of disbelief to immerse yourself; Bruce Wayne, and all his enemies, live inside vulnerable human bodies which are easily beaten and broken. They are supplemented often by high-tech gadgetry, but these are built from supposed military designs and follows, at least on the surface, known scientific concepts. For example: The Dark Knight shows Batman’s night-vision developed from sonar technology, indicating that his only real power is his wealth.

Such realism helps us view the human stories behind Batman and his enemies. Batman and Joker are reflections of each other: both faced historical traumas but instead chose two different paths in life, yet both operate above the law and with a dictatorial authority. There’s a sense that these characters could feasibly exist in our world, and perhaps show a reflection of two extremes that either of us could fall into. Whereas characters like Thor and Dr. Strange transcend reality and time at a whim, highlighting and boasting the fact that, at least biologically, they are nothing like us, the viewer.

That’s why it took a few hours for Arkham Asylum to really win me over. In this game, Batman’s spandex clings for dear life against the absolutely ripped body of Bruce Wayne, and the Joker morphs into several inhuman entities which stretch far beyond the realms of realism that attached me so closely to the cinematic series. One of the villains first introduced is a giant animated Crocodile, which immediately broke my immersion despite the game’s incredibly detailed graphics.

However, after taking a conscious effort to drop my traditional thoughts of what Batman is, I started to find enjoyment in Arkham Asylum’s world. Despite Batman’s voice actor lacking the gruff aggression and edginess of Christian Bale, Ben Affleck and Robert Pattison, Mark Hamill does give a genuinely funny and energetic performance as The Joker. The best voice acting comes from the audiotapes scattered across Arkham, which record psychological evaluations of Batman’s various villains as they’re posed questions of simple ethics and world views. 

Batman uses Metroidvania-esque exploration which encourages you to revisit areas to unlock additional paths once you obtain the corresponding skill. For example: half way through Arkham you obtain a hacking device to blow out control boxes, opening up previously locked doors, as well as a zipline to traverse long gaps. What makes exploration so compelling is the tangible feeling of progression, as you obtain new ability, combined with the comfort of backtracking to previous locations. Most areas won’t take longer than 5 minutes to travel to, and will reveal trophies and audiotapes to further reveal backstory, all of which are genuinely interesting, including stories of Arkham’s warden and the events which shaped his life.

The game’s stealth system, on paper, feels the most “Batman” of all encounters as you pick off enemies one by one from the shadows. These sections are fairly difficult as armed enemies clump together, particular when they notice their fallen comrade hanging from a stone gargoyle or unconscious near a control panel. Some elements feel underbaked: for example, the inability to drag bodies into the shadows feels like a clear omission which causes enemies to go onto high alert with little you can do about it. 

The games hand-to-hand system feels too rudimentary to be fun. Most fistfights consist of button mashing with very few combos to learn, a somewhat unreliable counter attack system, and no real opportunity to think creatively or adjust your approach. There were additional combat rooms to complete at the end of the game, which is the only piece of content I didn’t feel compelled to complete. 

Overall though, Batman: Arkham Asylum faithfully taps into a wealth of comic book source material to deliver a satisfying Metroidvania explore-a-thon served with a rather mundane combat system. If, like me, your perception of Batman is shaped by recent onscreen outings, try view this as an alternative take on the series and play through with an open mind. There’s plenty to explore, and it provides a great introduction to the wider Batman universe.

149623322.review:
I'm not big on Batman -- something about the pointy ears and tights don't do it for me.

But damn, this game's great. As someone with zero nostalgia coming into these games -- Arkham Asylum stands as one of the easiest recommendations if you're craving a tidy experience that clocks in under 15-ish hours.

It's a smooth-ish mix between metroidvania, character action, and stealth -- all bundled in as tight of a package as Batman's batbulge. I love games with relentless level-to-level momentum; there is no wasted time as you're constantly being presented with new villains, gadgets, and encounter gimmicks.

And yeah, the brawling sections have aged quite a bit [i](especially the boss encounters, like yikes they're not great)[/i], but BUDDY -- Arkham Asylum is still representing some of the best stealth systems in games. Enemy AI progressively gets smarter and slightly sporadic as you dismantle the stealth puzzlebox, so they'll start moving in pairs, dart their vision backwards, and even start checking grates/vents. There's just so much to love in this game -- and UGH I almost forgot to mention the backtracking dopamine just hits the right metroidvania cog in my ape brain.

I loved my time in Asylum, and I can't wait to play Arkham City next! I've always heard great things and I'm very excited.

I just bought all 4 Arkham games and am playing through them chronologically. Obviously, this was first in line and did not disappoint in the slightest. The concept was so cool, typically you see inmates breaking out of Arkham so being trapped on the island with the villains for a change was super cool. The music was dope, the atmosphere was tense and it was an awesome experience to play. The gameplay was fairly simple, not too hard or complicated (though I really need to learn to counter better). I will say, playing on Normal mode, the bosses started out really good but I think they got continuously repetitive which kinda became a drag, especially later on with some particular bosses. I'm just starting my second playthrough on hard so if that changes with the mode I'll write that here, but overall the bosses were pretty tough which was nice. However*********SPOILER*********the final boss is very underwhelming compared to bosses played previously. It was almost pathetically easy how quickly the final battle came and went compared to how many times I died trying to beat other bosses********END SPOILER*********

In the end, this was a fairly simple yet still cool and atmospheric game and I thoroughly enjoyed playing it and will enjoy completing it :)

So, for yall that don’t know, I’m guessing everyone knows anyway, this is the first Arkham game and it shows, the game is great, to be fair every Arkham game is GREAT. If for some reason you aint played this game yet, and you are a batman fan, I wholeheartedly recommend it, it often goes on sale and it’s a very pleasant experience. 
However, as I previously said this is the first game, and it shows, the story is great but, no spoilers, the ending has much to be desired, and overall, the story was, in my opinion kinda, almost too, short, furthermore there are no side quests, apart from collecting Riddler trophies if that even qualifies as a side quest. Now, the combat absolutely redefined the genre, a lot of games have copied this type of combat, but its not entirely polished, the combat is kind of junky, it sometimes works sometimes doesn’t, with this said, this DOES NOT affect the story or campaign whatsoever, but it turned out to be sometimes frustrating in challenge maps, from what I experienced the game often ruins your combo even after taking down every enemy, and it has a clunky feel to it.

149542149.review:
Batman: Arkham Asylum ha sido un videojuego galardonado por diversidad de públicos tanto en su auge como en la actualidad. No soy mas que un internauta mas pero, a pesar de ello, no puedo contener mis ganas de expresar lo grandiosa y gloriosa que ha sido esta aventura.
Probablemente, lo mas característico de esta obra es su sistema de pelea "Freeflow". Un sistema que, a base de un creciente combo junto con la habilidad y sagacidad del jugador, permite a Batman ejecutar movimientos cada vez mas excéntricos, efectivos y satisfactorios. Este sistema hace sentir al jugador como una pluma en el viento, saltando de maleante en maleante de forma tan libre que puedes apreciarte como el verdadero Batman. Al continuar la historia y por consecuente dominar el sistema de pelea, puedes llegar a disfrutar de un espectáculo marcial increíble con poco y nada de esfuerzo.
En este juego, los titanes han sido explotados al máximo. Por consecuente, las batallas de jefes no se sienten tan impactantes y únicas incluyendo incluso al jefe final. Sin embargo debo destacar a las batallas contra Killer Croc y Scarecrow, magnificas y únicas batallas que realmente cumplen su cometido. Por un lado: Las alcantarillas se sienten mas peligrosas que nunca con la presencia del merodeador cocodrilo, quien estará asechando desde las profundidades en busca de la mas mínima perturbación en las aguas. Puedes sentirte aterrorizado realmente, ya que no sabes en que momento será que Killer Croc saltará sobre tí. Scarecrow, por el otro lado, ofrece una divertida sección de plataformas cada vez que te lo topas. Debes tener mucho cuidado con tus movimientos, ya que puede que seas visto por el villano y tu partida termine.
Los trofeos de acertijo son algo que odias o amas, hay un total de 240 acertijos siendo algunos literales adivinanzas, otros trofeos y también los dientes de Joker destruidos. Si te gusta completar las cosas en su totalidad, estos pequeños acertijos van a desafiar tu inteligencia, memoria y hasta conocimiento del mundo DC. pero de tal forma que no se hace tedioso ni aburrido (por lo menos para mi).
Con todo esto dicho, puedo decir que ha sido un placer completar este juego al 100%. No me arrepiento de nada, y espero que este juego nunca sea olvidado. Se trata de nada mas ni nada menos que de una de las obras mas gloriosas de la historia de los videojuegos.

149541532.review:
This is the first Batman game I played and WOW what a great game it was! I got hooked instantly and the combat gameplay is probably one of the best combat systems i have seen in a game. It was just very fun to punch the living crap out of the henchmen and bosses.

 I don't know if the AI is different in other difficulty settings but i played on hard (which is the most difficult one) and the AI for just simple thugs could sometimes kill the Batman, which often made for some good laughs. Nothing was as amusing as thinking you made an cool escape only to get sniped by a thug in the back. I might think that hard difficulty would not be so enjoyable for some players, but i personally really liked it. But i still suggest trying on medium on your first time.

 I never really delved into the Batman universe that much before but after playing this game i re watched the Nolan Batman trilogy and bought the other games in the Arkham series when they were on sale. I really liked finding the extras stuff like Character BIOS and voice logs which really got me interested in the Batman lore. 
The setting, the characters, the story feels sometimes very raw which i really like and it doesn't treat you like a helpless kid. Its gritty, atmospheric, entertaining and most of all fun to play. 

The only complaint i would have is that the ending kinda came out of nowhere and could have been a bit longer. It could feel a bit more climactic. Other than that solid game i highly recommend!

9/10

149520413.review:
I had always heard good things about the old Batman games, but never got around to playing them. At this point I was a little worried they would not hold up or would have issues running on modern hardware, as some older games do. Thanks to a recent bundle, I’ve discovered that both of thees worries were unfounded.

Batman: Arkham Asylum has aged fantastically well. Sure, no one is going to look at this and think it is a recent game, but it still looks very good and for the most part controls quite well. While models, textures, and lighting may look outdated, none of them look so outdated that I would have thought this game was almsot 15 years old. I guess part of that is the slow and minor graphical year to year improvements we’ve been seeing lately for the most part. On the other hand, the way Batman’s cape flows and moves looks quite good, even by today’s standards.

As far as controls go, for the most part the game feels like any other new game. The thing that stands out to me as odd is how sprint, climb, interact, and dodge are all bound to the same button. It definitely ages the game, but it’s also not that hard to adjust to.

Map area’s may be small, but they feel fairly detailed and thanks to the quick loading, I barley noticed most of the loading screens when going between buildings and rooms. Combine that with great performance, other than the occasional stutter, and the game actually feels better than many modern games when it comes to fluidity of the world.

As for gameplay, you play as Batman, exploring Arkham Asylum and defeating a bunch of escaped criminals who are helping Joker do some evil plan. To do this you do standard video game stuff like fighting enemies and solving environmental puzzles. I don’t think any of this was original even when the game first came out, but for the most part its executed quite well so it feels fun.

By far the worst part is fighting enemies with guns. Even with maxed out armour upgrades, they kill you in under 5 seconds, usually before you can get a single punch in. Your only really option is to stealth kill them, which can be quite finicky at times. You also pretty much have to kill them all in stealth without getting caught. While you can go back into hiding, if you are seen, you are pretty much always killed before you have the chance to hide again. Luckily most combat does not have any guns, but every time I see a room with gunners, I just want to give up and stop playing. They are that frustrating to deal with.

Overall, Batman: Arkham Asylum is a great game that holds up very well that I would very much recommend, especially considering you can pick it up for under 5 bucks.

It’s refreshing to play a Triple A mainstream game that sticks to the source material, where the main focus of the game is for the player to have an enjoyable experience, you don’t get that too much in modern Triple A slop. The characters and the dialog are very well written and voice acted. If you didn’t know anything about the Batman lore, you will after playing this game.

The gameplay revolves around stealth segments, beat em’ up segments, and collect-a-thon segments (Riddler Trophies) and works out well.

If you’re mostly a fan of modern day cape sh*t sloppa, and have a wall of Funko Pops behind you, then this game probably isn’t for you, but if you’re a fan of old school comic books, then it is a must play.

149402986.review:
Arkham Asylum is where it all started for the modern Superhero game. 

Whilst the combat system feels somewhat basic by today's standards, it holds up surprisingly well even without the bells and whistles that would be introduced in the sequels. Stealth gameplay is still just as satisfying as it always was, making predator encounters an absolute blast to go through. 

Visually the game holds up extremely well due to solid art direction and barring the final boss encounter, the story remains a basic but effective Batman tale and a brilliant introduction to the DC mythos for any newcomers. 

Finally, both the Combat and Predator challenge maps are a fun, competitive bit of challenge for anyone who enjoys 1-upping their friend's high scores or honing strategies to their maximum potential. 

Batman: Arkham Asylum is a must-play for fans of Batman and of course, a great experience for all skill levels. Though, Arkham City remains my personal favourite.

149300095.review:
Holy Bat-bananas, folks! If you've ever wondered what happens when you mix the World's Greatest Detective with a madhouse full of the craziest villains Gotham has to offer, look no further than Batman: Arkham Asylum. Spoiler alert: it's a riot!

The Bat-tastic Adventure:
So, picture this: Batman, looking all broody and cape-y, decides to take the Joker for a leisurely stroll to Arkham Asylum. I mean, what could possibly go wrong, right? Well, everything. It's like the Joker planned a surprise party for Bats, and by "surprise party," I mean he invited all his Arkham buddies to play a game of "Let's See Who Can Give Batman the Biggest Headache."

Bat-nanas Gadgets:
Let's talk gadgets. Batman's utility belt is basically the Swiss Army Knife of superhero accessories. Need to hack into a security system? Batarang! Need to take out a bunch of henchmen without breaking a sweat? Explosive Gel! It's like Batman went shopping at the "Bad Guys Be Gone" store, and everything was half off.

Arkham's Got Talent:
Now, let's talk about the inmates. Arkham Asylum is like the talent show from hell. You've got the Joker, who's basically a stand-up comedian with a really twisted sense of humor. Poison Ivy is there, making plants do her bidding. And let's not forget Killer Croc - a guy who takes "going green" to a whole new level. It's like the Justice League went on vacation, and Gotham's rogues' gallery decided to throw a party.

Detective Mode:
Oh, and Batman's Detective Mode? It's like his version of Insta-filter for crime scenes. He just puts on his super cool glasses, and suddenly, he can see footprints, analyze trajectories, and probably even tell you what the Riddler had for breakfast. It's almost unfair how good he is at crime-solving.

The Bat-voice:
Let's take a moment to appreciate Batman's gravelly voice. I mean, seriously, if I tried talking like that, I'd need a throat lozenge within five minutes. But Batman? He growls, and bad guys quiver in their mismatched socks. It's like having Clint Eastwood and a chainsaw in the same room.

Conclusion:
Batman: Arkham Asylum is like a wild night out in Gotham - full of crazy characters, mind-blowing gadgets, and enough bat-punching action to make you question why Batman doesn't have his own cooking show. If you haven't played it yet, do yourself a favor and dive into the madness. It's Bat-tastic!

149191705.review:
The game has a great story and the visuals in some ways are stilldecent, partly because it seems to be a hybrid between a drawn comic look and 3d models, but that's where the good stuff stops.

The controls are extremely clunky oftentimes I lose fights not because of wrong reactions, but because for example a dodge automatically targets nearby enemies to jump over them resulting in dodging into a line of fire instead of out of it. Also traversal controls suck, gliding is something that's ingame but you're better off not using and the grapple hook is only usable when standing firmly on the ground below a potential grappling point. 

Also the loading of the game is pretty bad, sometimes you load in with random spikes jutting through things.

But the biggest issue is that it needs to be constantly online but somehow doesn't properly register your connectivity so even if you have stable connection it still might constantly put you back in the main screen because of dropped connection. This bug makes the game borderline unplayable sometimes.

That said, the voice acting and art style for most things are great, though the models lack expressiveness and often have very weird body language for the conversations being held, so if it's on sale and you have the patience to not always being able to play it when you wish to, it might be fun to play when it's on at least a 50% sale.

I never bothered playing these games because game adaptions of movies tend to be cash grabs. Not only that, but when I picked up all 3 games together on sale I was considering skipping this one due to it's age, but I am so glad I didn't.

This game exceeded my expectations massively, its game-play and combat have aged amazingly and it was far more of a blast than I expected. A really cool cinematic experience that feels open yet linear at the same time.

Also the graphics hold up surprisingly well, especially the PhysX physics - the water and fog simulations look more realistic than a lot of games today. Scarecrows scenes with the non euclidean spaces are a trip.

All in all it reminds me that games used to be far less of an "industry" and more just really cool stuff being made by really talented people.

149164893.review:
Batman: Arkham Asylum is a legendary title that truly sets the standard for superhero-themed video games. As a devoted Batman fan, I couldn't have asked for a better interactive experience within the world of the Dark Knight.

The game's setting, Arkham Asylum itself, is a character in its own right. The eerie and foreboding atmosphere, combined with the Gothic architecture, makes for a perfect backdrop to this thrilling adventure. Exploring the asylum feels like a journey into madness, and it's filled with cleverly designed puzzles and hidden secrets.

The combat system is exceptional, allowing you to feel like the ultimate detective and martial artist. The fluidity of the combat, along with Batman's vast array of gadgets, keeps every encounter engaging and satisfying. The stealth gameplay is equally impressive, emphasizing the importance of strategy and cunning as you silently take down armed foes.

The story is where Arkham Asylum truly shines. It's a dark and gripping tale that brings together some of Batman's most iconic foes, with Mark Hamill's portrayal of the Joker being a standout performance. The voice acting and writing are top-notch, immersing you in a thrilling narrative that keeps you guessing at every turn.

The game's attention to detail and reverence for the source material is evident in every nook and cranny. Riddler trophies, patient interviews, and character profiles add depth to the experience, making you feel like the World's Greatest Detective.

In conclusion, Batman: Arkham Asylum is a must-play not only for Batman fans, but for anyone looking for a phenomenal gaming experience. Embrace the darkness and dive into this extraordinary adventure in the shoes of the Dark Knight.

I'll be honest, I know I'm many, MANY years late on this, but I finally got around to playing this recently and I am so underwhelmed I needed to post about it should anyone else be in the same boat.

So upfront, I watched the live action show and cartoon as a kid, but beyond that I've not been huge into Batman since then, maybe that's my problem, but the amount of praise the game gets I'd expect it to hold up even without being invested in the franchise. Apparently not (for me at least).

If I had to use one word to summarise it all I'd say the game is "Repetitive" because so many times I found myself saying "oh this, AGAIN".

How many times do I need to fight enemies that need to be Batarang'ed as they charge, dodge and punch? How many times do I need to beat up wave after wave of random low level nobodies?
How many times do I need to fight [spoiler]Scarecrow[/spoiler]?

Honestly the idea that this game was a Game of the Year is more a damning statement about the quality of games the year it came out than about the quality of this game. I nearly uninstalled after the second [spoiler]Scarecrow[/spoiler] section because I just could not be bothered anymore, but I checked to see if I was anywhere near the end and apparently there wasn't too much left so I pushed on to see if it got any better and Jesus Christ the final boss fight was the most anti-climactic fight I think I have ever played.

The only thing I can think of that got this game so many good reviews (not just on Steam but in general) was because it was a super hero game and it was being judged against the quality of previous franchise tie in games.

149041046.review:
Batman: Arkham Asylum is a fantastic superhero action game set on the infamous prison island containing some of the most messed-up villains to ever trouble the good citizens of Gotham.  Of course, Batman's arch-enemy, Joker, is incarcerated here, and the story revolves around progressing through the prison, dealing with his henchmen and other super-villains such has Harley Quinn, Poison Ivy and Killer Croc.

The environments you move through are extremely well done, from the open spaces on the island between the prison buildings to the depths of the prison itself, which are dark, spooky and in some cases downright terrifying!  The Grapnel Gun allows freedom of movement to get to places where you can observe and plan your next encounter using your "detective vision".

You gain a formidable arsenal of toys to deal with you enemies, and they're all fun to play with.  The combat system allows you to chain together combos as you deal with groups of enemies.  It can be frustrating at times, but you soon get the hang of it.  The boss encounters will probably also take you several attempts as you learn the timing of their attacks, either countering with an attack of your own, or just getting out of the way!

Beyond the combat there are many collectables scattered across the game, including Joker Teeth, Riddler Trophies and interview tapes with some of Arkham's inmates.  Finding these gives you experience points that can be used to unlock weapon upgrades.

148843575.review:
Greetings, citizens of Steam! It's the one and only Caped Crusader here, and I've taken a brief respite from patrolling the mean streets of Gotham City to share my thoughts on Batman: Arkham Asylum GOTY Edition.

Review:

As I descended into the eerie depths of Arkham Asylum, I couldn't help but think, "Why don't the inmates ever stay put?" But that's beside the point, and now, it's time for a Bat-review.

🦇 The True Batman Experience 🦇

Arkham Asylum GOTY Edition is the closest thing you'll get to becoming me without, well, becoming me. It's as close as you can get to patrolling the rooftops and grappling onto gargoyles, all without breaking a sweat. I mean, I don't sweat. But you get the idea.

🤖 Gadgets Galore 🤖

My utility belt is like a Bat-candy store, complete with explosive gel and the Batarang, perfect for knocking down pesky thugs and leaving them bewildered. I give it five Bat-thumbs up! Wait, I only have two thumbs, but you get the point.

🧩 Riddle Me This, Riddler! 🧩

The Riddler has left his little puzzles and trophies strewn all over the place. It's like he's got a competitive streak. Don't worry; I cracked those riddles faster than I can say, "I'm Batman."

🦹 Rogues' Gallery Face-Off 🦹

The villains of Arkham Asylum are like a who's who of Gotham's criminal elite. Joker, Scarecrow, Poison Ivy, and more. It's like a criminal family reunion, but with more Batarangs and fewer awkward conversations.

🦚 Stealth Mode: Like a Bat Ninja 🦚

My stealth skills are unparalleled, and you'll get to experience that firsthand. Sneaking up on unsuspecting henchmen is a bit of a hobby of mine. I like to imagine I'm the Batman version of a ninja in a cape.

💣 Exploding Fun 💣

Joker's explosive surprises are just the kind of fireworks Gotham needs. It's almost as if he wants me to know he's always watching. And he's right; I'm Batman—I'm always watching too!

Conclusion:

In the grand tradition of the Dark Knight, Batman: Arkham Asylum GOTY Edition is a masterpiece. It's like stepping into the cowl, except without all the training and brooding. So, citizens of Steam, if you've ever wondered what it's like to be Batman, wonder no more. Dive into Arkham Asylum and unleash your inner vigilante. After all, I'm Batman, and I approve this game.

🦇 Bat-Approved Rating: 9.5/10 - "The game Gotham deserves and needs!" 🦇

Still a great game.

I went back and played this game as I got it in a bundle on sale. I originally played this game back in 2012-ish and figured I'd give it a replay to see if it still holds up. It does, although the graphics are obviously a bit dated, it doesn't hold the game back at all as the voice acting and animations are still very well done. 

The gameplay is the tried and true 3rd person stealth/action beat-em-up that laid the formula for many successful franchises since. There are some gameplay and combat issues still present that  have  been cleaned up in more recent games that utilize the same mechanics, however it rarely becomes a major issue in the core gameplay loop. 

Would recommend anyone who is a fan of this style of games gives this one a go as it is an all time classic that still holds up.

148754101.review:
SteamDeck 10/10. I have no idea why its not verified, it even plays in the native aspect ratio. Smooth experience from my play time with no settings adjusted. 

I am not a DC fan (read as I really, really don't like DC), and I'm hardly interested in Batman. I am much more into Marvel (read as I really, really love Marvel). This game is borderline perfect. You don't have to be a Batman fan, just a fan of good video games to really enjoy Batman: Arkham Asylum. This game is from an era just before all the micro transaction/live services BS really started to take off and take hold of the mainstream market. It's a complete package from beginning to end with a solid amount of content that wraps up very nicely in the end. I got this game on sale for a meager 3 bucks, the price of a McChicken these days and had a blast. I bought it and gave it a shot more because I know the reputation it has and have heard great things about this game. Everyone was right, and I am horribly late to the party. 

Batman: Arkham Asylum is a metroidvania lite in a lot of good ways. This is a character action game first, and it really nails a good feel for the combat. The buttons make sense, the attacks thrown at you are well telegraphed, each combat encounter rewards your methodical approach rather than just button mashing. It feels great to control Batman. The developers did a great job of capturing "feeling like Batman". As you progress there will be areas and secrets inaccessible to you until you unlock certain equipment or upgrades. There is some clever back tracking, with a lot of surprising level design changes as you continue through your adventure. The enemy variety throughout the game is just right for the length of the total campaign and stayed fresh enough through my play through. Some combat encounters can be pretty boring, particularly against the over-sized brutes. But when you're fighting normal goons, exploring Arkham Asylum, and solving puzzles this game is amazing. The world design, art direction, and character acting are really good and serves to sell the immersion in a great way. Some cut-scene work is meh, but it never took away from enjoyment of the game and served just to be a quick stepping stone to the next thing.

I give Batman: Arkham Asylum a 9/10 and I can see my self coming back to play it again. The only thing really holding it back from a solid 10 is some of the combat encounters I could do without or should have been made more interesting. Otherwise, this is incredible game that everyone should give a play through.

148751226.review:
It's good but I got a few little notes about it.

Some of the animations can't be stopped once you started them and can only be stopped until you wait the whole time or get hit by a goon. The guns are kinda op against Batman. 

SPOILER PART:
Boss fights were... Okay but needed more of everything. 
BANE: Bane is a pretty easy boss once you figure out what to do and what not to do, which makes sense cause he's the first boss.
Then they have like 5-6 bane remakes that you have to fight through the game which operate exactly like bane. Only difference between the drugged up goon fights and bane is that the drugged up goons normally have other goons with them. Got kinda boring having to keep fighting them.

SCARECROW: His "Fights" Are pretty much you running forward trying not to be seen by his light... That's pretty much it. You fight skeletons every so often, but they are easier to fight than goons. They also have skelly's that fight the same as jacked up goons, but are even easier to fight cause all you gotta do is dodge them once and they explode.

Harley Quinn: Legit just stay off the electro-floor and beat up goons.

CROC: Croc's fight is pretty much just walk on platforms (can't run or you'll die) And collect stuff. He'll pop up every so often, but all you gotta do is throw one batatararaang at him. I wouldn't really call it a boss fight.

IVY: Ivy has a lot of "Power" in  this game, and yet she's easy to fight. Legit dodge her easily dodge-able moves while spamming batarangs at her. Then place and explosive on her. You gotta do this whole things twice, but that's all her fight is.

JOKER: Joker's fight is by FAR the biggest JOKE of the whole game.. It's the last fight and yet is the easiest.... Like super easy.. He turns into a jacked joker and all you gotta to is dodge his attacks (like 5 attacks) then he will jump off the arena and send his men in. After spending like 1-2 mins killing his men, you pull him down and punch him. You do that whole thing 3 times. Doesn't get any harder tbh. You also get more health between the rounds, so it's even easier. 


That's the whole game, not very long. If you tried to speedrun it first time playing, you could beat it in 6h.
You could do it in that amount of time not speed running it, tbh. I got 8h while taking pause breaks and exploring. 


BUT, It wasn't bad and was good when it came out. Graphics aren't too old, game play isn't ... THAT bad, and batman still be doing bat things.

148709852.review: I played this game back in 2009 on the Xbox 360 and was blown away by how fantastic the graphics looked. This was one of the few games where it truly felt like a huge generational leap from the PS2/Xbox/Gamecube era. The combat was unlike anything I've ever seen at the time, and was one of the main draws for me. The graphics still hold up even to this day, especially when you look up close to the characters like the Joker and the attention to detail with his facial features. This game does a magnificent job of making you feel like Batman, everything from the combat to the grappling to sneaking up behind enemies and knocking them out cold. All of the gameplay elements are fused together so beautifully - platforming, beat-em-up, puzzle solving, treasure hunt, stealth...there's never a dull moment. The music is top notch, and really adds to the dark and gritty atmosphere. To hear the legendary Kevin Conroy voice as Batman is like premium icing on the cake. Overall, this is a brilliantly crafted game from start to finish.

148566212.review: Batman:Arkham Asylum is a must-play for me. Combat, while easy for me now as I have been playing through this game so many times(which probably should explain my liking for it), still offers a satisfying experience in superhero battle design. Stealth can be enjoyed too. I will say that it's not as dynamic as say, Splinter Cell(the original), as for example the player is unable to hide bodies and noise can be avoided at all the right time if you know when to stop running and when to crouch. It's a simple system of stealth considering stealth-based games I've played in the past. However, gunfire from the armed guards Batman is up against will always pack a punch to the player's HP, even if they manage to barely survive the stealth room by fighting their way through which I don't is possible? I mean, at least not very consistently. Of course, here's a pro tip, singling out the guards will leave the one defenseless and completely open to a trial by combat approach. Try not to be in their line of sight however if you want to do him a "PERFECT K.O.". Overall, Batman:Arkham Asylum is a mechanically simple game when you narrow it down. Yet, it remains satisfying and there is also plenty of depth to be mined out of it. You will be punished appropriately if you approach groups of enemies incorrectly and sneaking can be heavily punished if done poorly. However, when those things are done right, it's incredibly satisfying. It always feels great whenever I am able to quickly and handily dismantle a room full of armed henchmen or defeat all enemies in an encounter with as little difficulty as possible. It, without question, can make you feel like Batman. Play it well, and you are for sure worthy of taking control of the Caped Crusader himself. Excellent.

148531055.review:
A game from 2010 that supports ultrawide, has no bugs and has a loot of fan service? Well just that earns a recommendation from me, but lets talk a bit more about it.

Batman Arkham Asylum is a cult classic, but hear my opinion on it as an outsider.
I like the old batman movies, but I wouldn't class myself as a batman fan.
Having said that, I found the game to be good, maybe not amazing, but definitely good enough to warrant a playthrough.
The gameplay is interesting and varied, you unlock new tools as you progress that give you more options for traversal and the ability to reach places that you couldnt before. It all uses the same map, but you just get higher levels of access with time.
The story is relatively simple, but there is a lot of fan service for people that have read the old comics, so this will be lovely for fans of batman (though one could argue that there maybe was a bit too much fan service? I'll leave that for you to decide). 
The graphics have aged like fine wine since the artstyle still feels very relevant for a comic book superhero game.

The only two real issues (albeit minor) I had were related to - the voice acting (seems like the audio captured was low bitrate or something else, but batmans voice specifically sounds scuffed) and the amount of one liner dialogue (honestly, a little cringe).

Having said all of that, I still enjoyed the game. It didn't overstay its visit, clocking in at around 12 hours for me (ignoring the idle time and bonus content) and was a nice change of cpace compared to big bombastic open world games of today.
You can usually get it at a huge discount as well so its a no brainer, give it a try!

2009'da hangi PC'ye çıkan oyunlar büyük yankı yaptı? COD MW2, Borderlands, Prototype, Assassin's Creed 2, Left 4 Dead 2, Batman Arkham Asylum... Bunlar şahsen benim oynayıp gördüklerim arasından. Ve hepsi hakkında düşüncelerim ne çok iyi ne de kötü oldukları yönünde. Yani 'iyiler ama o kadar' olduğunu düşündüğüm oyunlar. Arkham Asylum'da belirttiğim gibi bunlar arasında.

Hepimiz önceden bir Batman oyunu oynamışızdır bence. Ya NES'ten ya PS2'den hatta bazılarımız Kraloyundan vs illa bir şekilde oynamıştır. Ve hiçbiri de iyi oyunlar değiller. Hatta birçoğu rezalettir çoğumuza göre. Fakat 2008'de Rocksteady yaptı duyurusunu. Adamlar oyun dünyasında rezalet etki bırakmış olan Batman'in oyununu yapıyorlardı. Riskli ama temiz bir hareket oldu benim açımdan. Çünkü oyun iyi. Hikayesinden bahsetmek istemiyorum. Doğru düzgün hatırlamıyorum bile. Tek hatırladığım 11-12 saat boyunca Joker'in peşine vermemiz. Oyun boyunca Joker'in peşindeyiz. Ha arada başka düşmanlar da geliyor. Hatta baya düşman geliyor. Scarecrow, Killer Croc, Harley Quinn, Bane, Zsasz gibi bir sürü düşman var lakin oyunun bunlara ayırdığı süreyi toplasanız anca 1.5-2 saat eder. Düşman bakımından kadro geniş ama pek iyi değerlendirilmemiş. Zaten boss savaşları rezalet. Hatta bu saydıklarım arasından Bane ve Joker dışında boss savaşı denebilecek bir olay da olmuyor. Hatta ve hatta Joker'in boktan bossuna boss demek bile istemiyorum.

Neyse sakinleşip oynanışı anlatmaya çalışayım. Kusursuza yaklaşmış, ne kadar övsem azdır. Kombolar o kadar akıcı ve zevkli ki 4 köşe ediyor insanı oyunun başlarında. Gizlilik kısımlarını aksiyon kısımlarından bile daha güzel buldum. Upgrade sistemi hiç fena değil. Oldukça iyi. Batman'in alet edevatları da ayrı bi tad katıyor tabii oynanışa. Bunu oynamayan bir insanın oyunların genel gameplay'ine bakış açısı, etsiz çiğköfteye benzer. Bulmacalar, yan görevler, challenge'lar derken oyunun 15-20 saatlik ömrü var. Yine de Spirit of Amadeus Arkham yan görevinin sonunda hayal kırklığına uğradığımı belirtmek isterim. O kadar saat harcadığıma değmedi şahsen o göreve.

Ve seslendirmeler... İşte bu kusursuz. Mark Hamill, Kevin Conroy, Tara Strong... En iyi seslendirmecileri toplamışlar resmen.

Güzel güzel. Puan verecek olsam:

Hikaye: 68
Seslendirmeler: 97
Oynanış: 95
Yan etkinlikler: 65
Grafik: 90
Haritası: 80

Genel: 75

İyi oyunlar!

As someone who has played many games over the years, I found Batman: Arkham Asylum to be a fantastic and engaging experience. The game’s mature themes and intricate storyline were a refreshing change from the often simplistic storytelling found in many modern games.

The game’s mechanics are well-designed, striking a good balance between challenge and accessibility. The combat system is intuitive and deep, allowing for strategic planning and execution. The stealth elements are particularly satisfying, requiring patience and careful observation.

The graphics are impressive, even years after its initial release. The dark and gritty atmosphere of Arkham Asylum is beautifully rendered, immersing you in the world of Batman. The attention to detail in the environment and character designs adds depth to the gaming experience.

The voice acting is top-notch, with Kevin Conroy and Mark Hamill reprising their roles as Batman and Joker, respectively. Their performances add authenticity to the game and enhance the narrative.

However, as an older player, I found some aspects of the game to be a bit challenging. The fast-paced combat sequences can sometimes be overwhelming, especially during boss fights. Additionally, some puzzle elements require quick reflexes, which can be a bit tricky for some older gamers.

Despite these challenges, I appreciate the game’s difficulty settings, which allow you to customize the gameplay experience to your skill level. This feature makes the game accessible to players of all ages and abilities.

In conclusion, Batman: Arkham Asylum - Game of the Year Edition for PC is an incredibly well-crafted game that offers a rich narrative, engaging gameplay mechanics, and stunning visuals. It’s a game that caters to its mature audience and provides a rewarding experience for those willing to immerse themselves in its dark and complex world.

Title: Batman: Arkham Asylum - A Decade Later, Still Delivering an Elite Superhero Experience

Rating: 4.5/5

As someone who has recently played Batman: Arkham Asylum, a decade after its release, it is evident that this game remains a pioneer in delivering an outstanding superhero experience. Despite being late to the party, I was captivated by the unique combat system, the integration of Batman's gadgets, and the immersive storytelling, which collectively make you feel like the legendary Dark Knight himself.

One of the standout features of Arkham Asylum is its combat system. Even after playing numerous contemporary games, Arkham Asylum's combat remains a cut above the rest. It perfectly captures the essence of Batman's martial arts prowess, allowing players to effortlessly transition between strikes, counters, and evasions. Every successful maneuver feels empowering, enabling players to single-handedly take on hordes of enemies with a satisfying blend of finesse and brute force. The combat is fluid and responsive, making you truly feel like the unstoppable Dark Knight.

The inclusion of Batman's extensive gadget arsenal is another commendable aspect of the game. From the Batarang to explosive gel, each gadget is seamlessly integrated into gameplay scenarios, providing dynamic solutions for both stealth and combat encounters. The game encourages players to experiment with different gadgets, adding depth to the overall experience and making you feel like a resourceful and strategic superhero.

The attention to detail in recreating the infamous Arkham Asylum is breathtaking. The asylum serves as an atmospheric and chilling backdrop for Batman's adventures, with its dark corridors, haunting environment, and uneasy atmosphere. Exploring the sprawling asylum feels like a genuine exploration of Batman's world, with secrets to uncover and mysteries to solve at every turn. The game's level design strikes a delicate balance between detailed architecture and player freedom, allowing for multiple approaches to each objective.

Furthermore, the storyline and voice acting in Arkham Asylum are on par with the best in the genre, even when compared to modern games. The narrative unfolds in a tightly paced manner, keeping players engaged and invested in Batman's mission to thwart the Joker's sinister plans. The voice cast, including Mark Hamill's iconic portrayal of the Joker, is outstanding, bringing the characters to life and immersing players in a truly cinematic experience.

While playing Arkham Asylum more than a decade later may result in occasional moments where certain aspects feel slightly dated, the overall quality and impact of the game's mechanics, storytelling, and atmosphere remain unparalleled. It is a testament to its excellence that it still holds up as one of the best superhero experiences even in the face of newer releases.

In conclusion, Batman: Arkham Asylum offers an exceptional and timeless gaming experience. Its unique combat system and clever integration of Batman's gadgets make you feel like the ultimate crime-fighting superhero. The atmospheric setting, engaging storyline, and remarkable voice acting further enhance the immersion and make you believe you truly are the Dark Knight. Despite playing it years after its initial release, Arkham Asylum effortlessly delivers an elite superhero adventure that is essential for fans of the caped crusader.

147995694.review:
Batman Arkham Asylum is an old game that has surprisingly aged well, but doesn't really stand up to the rest of the games in the series.

Batman Arkham Asylum's graphics look surprisingly good for a game that is this old. Characters have great designs that clearly showcase their personalities. The animations in this game also look pretty good. Sound design is pretty great. Hearing the crunches and cracks as you beat up enemies is greatly satisfying. Music here is really good as well and switch very smoothly from one another. The atmosphere presented by asylum is absolutely amazing and truly makes you feel the brutality of where you are. The art for this game is also pretty good.

Gameplay is good, but there are some flaws here and there. The combat is great, as it makes you feel like a dangerous martial artist. Attacks feel heavy and satisfying. Inputs are responsive, but sometimes when you throw a punch, Batman will just randomly swing a punch in the air when there is an enemy right next to him. The stealth sections are by far the best part of this game. Using your gadgets to gain an advantage over enemies and seeing their heart rate increase as the odds get turned against them truly makes you feel like a dangerous skilled assassin. Unfortunately these sections are few and far in between. The boss fights in this game are a mixed bag tho. Bane is way to simple to be fun, Killler Croc is way too easy, and the joker is just three waves of enemies. The only good boss is poison ivy. Puzzles are alright. Most of the puzzles that you will be solving is finding Riddler trophies. Luckily these are optional and they aren't as annoying and as common as they are in the rest of the series.

The story here is alright. Characters are interesting and well voiced by their voice actors. Unfortunately the overall story is a bit generic and weird decisions are often made by characters in the game. My favorite part though is the lore set up by this universe. The tapes that you collect during the game lets you listen to a therapy session that the villains went through and they are absolutely amazing and give you a great idea of how these characters think.

Overall, while there are some flaws here and there, this game is still really good and holds up quite well today, but don't expect it to be as good as the other games in the series.

147971236.review:
I am a huge Batman fan and this was the first Batman game I played which was rated M for Masterpiece.
Rocksteady created some smooth game mechanics which would redefine not only the Batman games, but many action games for two generations and, on top of it, they had also bought back Paul Dini to write the script, Kevin Conroy, Mark Hamill, Tara Strong and Arleen Sorkin to voice the characters.

It was a great fan service, especially for those who grew up watching the Diniverse, and it was a well deserved Game of The Year.

I remember playing this game for hours like more than 10 years ago and I couldn't help it but to pick it up again for PC. This is like a nice memory you keep revisiting every once in a while, which any Batman fan should experience at least once. The game features different difficulty settings to suit anyone, from casual gamers to more professional ones, we can also enjoy loads of hidden clues, Easter eggs and references to the DC universe which can make anyone smile. The game has aged well graphics and gameplay wise, and is not feeling dated even 14 years after it's initial release.

The game also gets serious, featuring the proper psycho nature of the Batman villains, which was watered down in the already mentioned Diniverse, but Paul Dini made the most of the nonrestrictive nature of this game and was able to do what Fox Kids won't allow him back in the day, when he worked on the Batman: The animated series or Justice League cartoons.

Especially in the lights of Kevin Conroy and Arleen Sorkin passing, this game stands out as extraordinary and offers us experiences we would never get again. Considering it's relative low price (especially during sales), this game is a must play.

147912015.review:
Title: An Absolute Masterpiece of the Batman Universe

Batman: Arkham Asylum is an absolute triumph in the world of video games, offering a thrilling and immersive experience that does justice to the iconic Dark Knight. From the moment I started playing, I was captivated by its gripping narrative, stunning visuals, and impeccable gameplay.

One of the standout features of Arkham Asylum is its exceptional storytelling. The game kicks off with Batman delivering the Joker to Arkham Asylum, but things quickly spiral out of control as the Clown Prince of Crime takes over the facility. The plot is filled with unexpected twists, keeping players on the edge of their seats throughout the game. The dialogue and voice acting are top-notch, with Mark Hamill's Joker and Kevin Conroy's Batman delivering unforgettable performances that rival their work in the animated series.

Visually, Arkham Asylum is a masterpiece. The attention to detail in the asylum's dark and foreboding corridors, as well as in Batman's suit and gadgets, is outstanding. The character models are incredibly lifelike, and the animation is smooth, which enhances the overall immersion.

The gameplay in Arkham Asylum is where the game truly shines. The combat system is both accessible to newcomers and rewarding for veterans, allowing players to feel like the caped crusader as they seamlessly chain together combos and counterattacks. Batman's arsenal of gadgets is vast and enjoyable to use, whether it's the grappling hook, batarangs, or the detective vision that lets you investigate crime scenes. The stealth mechanics are equally engaging, making it just as satisfying to stalk and subdue enemies in the shadows as it is to engage in all-out brawls.

The game also provides ample opportunities for exploration and puzzle-solving. The Riddler's challenges scattered throughout the island add an extra layer of depth to the gameplay, encouraging players to use their detective skills to solve riddles and collect trophies.

In addition to the main story, the game offers a plethora of side missions and unlockable content that extends its replayability. Arkham Asylum provides a rich and immersive experience that keeps players coming back for more.

In conclusion, Batman: Arkham Asylum is a triumph of game design and a must-play for both Batman fans and gamers in general. Its compelling narrative, stunning visuals, and impeccable gameplay combine to create an unforgettable experience that truly captures the essence of the Dark Knight. If you haven't experienced this masterpiece yet, do yourself a favor and dive into the world of Arkham Asylum; you won't be disappointed.

Everything that can be said about this game can most likely be said about City, Origins, And Knight. The combat, the story, the voice acting, the progression, the bosses, the music, Ar challenges, and the environment are significantly better in its sequels, but that does make Arkham Asylum any way bad. All those things I mentioned are all good in this game, but when you play the sequels; looking back on Arkham Asylum just doesn't feel the same as when you first played it.

There are some things  in my opinion that haven't been upgraded upon. That to me is the Scarecrow fights and the 3rd wall breaks. I know they've been similarly done in Origins and Knight, but I think that Asylum did a fantastic job on these parts. The Riddler challenges are fine but also boring; not much of a challenge; its really just you going back to places you've already been, but with more items.

Batman Arkham asylum is a good game to start the Arkham series with, and should be played by all to really appreciate on how the sequels have improved.

146673818.review:
This game is awesome in so many ways. It's just too short. Arkham City fixes that issue a bit, except that it kind of does it by way of adding a bunch of grindy side missions. That said, I'd much rather solve Riddler's puzzles in City over searching through all of Arkham Asylum again. I really hated the map design and found Asylum kind of a chore to navigate. At times, it kind of made me want to quit and move on to City.

The aesthetic of the game holds up, even ten years later. This game is truly a piece of art, and I don't think many games are like that. The mechanics are pretty good, just unrefined. You can see why City became so much better. Directional jumping is problematic in this game, which is mostly fine... except that there are a few platforming sections where it's really bothersome.

The one area where this game has City beat is in its story, which I think is way more interesting. Joker gets himself locked into Arkham Asylum, escapes, and begins reaping havoc. That story is way more interesting than City, which is a kind of half-baked superhero plot about Strange trying to control Arkham City/Gotham. I also think that there are too many enemy types in City. But that's for a different review.

All in all, this is a great game that's worth playing. It's just definitely NOT worth collecting all of the Riddler trophies because it's not worth working your way through the maze-like map.

7/10

146314771.review:
I can count on one hand, maybe two hands all the games I would call "masterpiece". This game (and its sequel) is one of them. 14 years later and this game still eclipses every single other superhero game out there. This is comfortably the best superhero game ever made. It is one of the best action games ever made. Its influence is still widely seen today.

Every once in a while a game comes along that innovates, changes up how things work, changes up gaming in general (e.g. Dark Souls - Soulslike genre). Arkham Asylum did just that back in 2009. Shortly after its release, we saw the first copycats emerge in the form of Shadow of Mordor and Mad Max, nowadays by the Spiderman games. All these games are imitators of the original. Not so impressive.

On top of that innovation, it still holds up visually, because of the stellar art design. Then you have the great stealth combat, the metroidvania level design that encourages backtracking, the immersive atmosphere, the excellent narrative, the fantastic character design, it all culminated into a true masterpiece and one of the very few games in existence that genuinely deserves a 10/10 score.

146148088.review:
[h1]It Makes You [i]Feel[/i] Like Batman[/h1]

Given the quality of games these days, in the fine year of 2023, it's truly hard to believe that this game came out in 2009. I missed this game on release because I was a broke college student, but have memories of everyone saying how good it was. And they were right! They're still right! This game aged remarkably and hearkens back to an era when we were drowning in solid new releases. An era that would soon be coming to an end. 

[h1]Where to Begin...[/h1]

There is so much to praise about this game: Fluid combat and movement. Good mix of combat, puzzle solving and platforming. Insanely good atmosphere. Great takes on classic Batman villains. Not too short, not too long. There's not a whole lot to really complain about (and I'll get to that). It's an all around good, engrossing experience that begs you to keep playing.

Back in 2009, [i]Arkham Asylum[/i] introduced an innovative combat system. Everything was streamlined. No complicated combos to memorize. Everything was contextualized. By doing this, players can easily take 
 control of Batman and acrobatically beat the pulp out of Joker's thugs. It just feels right as you see Batman effortlessly gliding through and between enemies, delivering punches left and right, occasionally having to counter, throwing the occasional baterang - or three. It all holds up nearly 15 years later. 

As the world's greatest detective, you'll also be challenged to solve puzzles, mysteries, and riddles. This is again another area Rocksteady streamlined. Anytime you need to figure something out, you just go into detective mode and stuff gets highlighted. Admittedly, this got stale after a while, but the middle ground would be tough to find. If you make puzzles too challenging, a lot of players will get frustrated and quit. If you dumb it down anymore, you remove the challenge all together. It gives you something to do where you can put in minimal effort and get rewarded. For [i]Arkham Asylum[/i], it needs some mechanic like this, as otherwise there would be no incentive to explore the island.

Lastly, I want to throw some praise at the atmosphere and mood of this game. Arkham is a dark place. There is not one trace of anything other than evil and depravity. As you explore the asylum, you pick up interviews with inmates and messages from the founder. From these stories it becomes immediately clear that there are no good guys at Arkham. Coupled with the detailed environments around the island, which were clearly inspired by psychiatric hospitals c.1930, exploring the asylum fills one with a sense of unease.

[h1]Minor Criticisms[/h1]

There isn't much bad to be said about this game, at least not from a design perspective. Fights with the Titan Henchmen, for example, were easily the weakest part of the game. One is introduced early on and then they aren't seen again for a while. The basic premise of these fights is simple, but they include my least favorite mechanic: Waiting.

The Titan Henchmen fight cycle is as follows:
-Wait for Titan to charge
-Quick throw baterang and dodge
-Titan hits wall, gets disoriented
-Avoid and wait for Titan to go back to normal state
-Repeat until you can knock him out

It's a lot of waiting. And then you get sections where there are multiple Titans, or multiple Titans with 10 other basic henchmen. In these cases when you knock a Titan down you can at least ride it and make it thrash around and hit enemies, but even then it's not that satisfying.

Having said all that, while I was playing I realized that nevertheless, the design choice to make you square off against 2 Titans and 10 henchmen is interesting in theory. To fight a Titan you have to wait. But you can't wait when you 10 guys all trying to attack you at once.  I really commend the idea of making a player perform 2 diametrically opposed tasks at the same time. Love the idea. Hated it in practice.

The only other issues I had were technical and I chalk them up to this game being old. Problems I experienced:
-Game freezing at start menu, forced restart
-Occasional bad input lag
-Stopped getting achievements for some reason

[h1]Overall[/h1]

Solid game. Definitely recommend. Still amazing to me that this, a game that came out in 2009, looks, runs, and feels better than pretty much everything that's come out in the last 10 years. [b]8/10.[/b]

146069406.review:
This is the quintessential manbat game if there ever was one. We get to see Arkham Asylum in all its gothic grotesquery, sneak around choking out perps dressed in tights and if that fails beating up hordes of working class goons that never got a fair chance to break the mold and join the wealthy middle class of Gotham.. The island where the titular Arkham Asylum is located is quite a sandbox filled with nooks and crannies where you can lurk upon your enemies or find the hidden psycho-paraphernalia. The story is nothing fantastic but fits the bill.. Joker gets put under lock and key, but wait! It was a master plan all along and now he controls the asylum! Luckily ManBat happens to be right there to save the day! On the way we run into a brief yet regular entourage of famous villains and monsters from the comics. It didn't bother me even though I always find body morphology in these kinds of games jaring..  

So yea, Batman Arkham Asylum is a great game and if nothing else a damn fine example of a stealth game done right. Combine that with a fluent, almost rhythm game based combat that looks truly cinematic at times and you get a dark and brooding ballet of chokeholds, batarangs, anti-shark sprays and mighty roundhouse kicks that put Chuck Norris to shame. If you like Batman on top of it all, I imagine it is even better. It’s always great to find a game that acknowledges the sneaky rat that lives in my brain!

146060638.review:
[u]In a nutshell:[/u] The Batman game, that started the Arkham legend.

The first game in the action-brawler Arkham series, laying the foundation on which the other three games are built. The controls may not be as sophisticated and polished as in the later games, but everything has to start somewhere. The combat is not my favourite part of the game, but the Dark Knight's movement and the gadgets feel absolutely awesome. The story is fascinating, with lots of little twists and turns, and features one of the most mind-bending 4th wall-breaking scenes in the entire gaming industry (Scarecrow's fear toxin).

[u]Recommended if:[/u] You like a dark detective story, an interesting take on well-known comic characters, and if you want to meet your favourite comic characters animated and voiced with a great attention to detail.
[u]Not recommended if:[/u] You are an achievement hunter, as most of the challenges feel not only hard, but also tedious and repetitive.

145977447.review: It's a classic and a must play for any Batman fan. It's the first entry in the Batman Arkham series of games and set the stage for the later sequels and prequels. You play as Batman and attempt to bring order to the mass breakout at Arkham orchestrated by the Joker. You face familiar villains such as Scarecrow, Killer Croc, Bane and others. The game is basically free roam of the Arkham Island, with new areas being unlocked as the story progresses or as new gadgets are added/found. There are many Batman easter eggs here and there, and the overall feel of the game has a dark, somewhat horror-esque feel to it. I'd recommend it for anyone curious and looking to get started in the Batman series of games.

This is the perfect game for a Batman fan!

This action beat'em up with stealth elements, puts you in Batman's boots after taking Joker into custody and sending him back "Home" to Arkham, but this time things are different, as this time the Joker has devised a plan to take over Arkham. 
Has the Joker trapped you inside with all of them? or are they the ones trapped in there with you?
This adventure will take you to meet and fight some of Batman's most iconic villains, Even getting to learn more about their story in the form of collectibles.
While I played on keyboard and mouse (without the option to remap keys), the game felt well enough to play and enjoy, still I would recommend using a controller.
The idea of having real riddles to solve and not only puzzles or mini games really made you feel like a detective… most of the time.

There was no yank apart from the odd getting stuck in geometry, but it never became a problem.
And while sometimes it felt like Batman had a mind of his own doing stuff unprompted or the wrong prompt thing being done, apart from it breaking a perfectly good combo or leaving an open for my enemies to attack me, I didn't rage as much as I thought I would so it wasn't that disruptive.

145488328.review:
It is difficult for me to recommend Arkham Asylum, I believe everyone should play at least the story on easy, just to experience what a comic can become on a media other than movies, videogames allow so much more, and this game is proof of that, while most Batman movies are amazing, they are unable to cover everything the comics have to offer, and may Dunkey strike me down, but this game DOES make you feel like Batman.

However, the game it's old, and it shows, the combat has aged bad in my honest opinion and made me rage more than a few times when I was pressing the damn button but it didn't respond, but that's on me for playing on hard. Yet talking about the gameplay as a whole, it redeems itself with other features, especially the detective mode, for the first time Batman actually becomes the world's best detective, using tons of gadgets and tools to solve every mystery Arkham has, beating Riddler on his own game and making the search for his trophies a very enjoyable hunt.

The graphics while old, hold up pretty well, yet for some reason, as most games from around 2000's it has the yellow filter, but not so strong as to make it look like piss, the game being set at night helps a lot though.

The story wasn't really something truly new or unexpected, and to be honest I don't think Joker would become what he did at the ending, I believe it's not something he would do, but the whole adventure was fun, loved the performances of Mark Hamill and Kevin Conroy. In conclusion, combat is hard to get used to, Batman becomes his true self throughout the story, and the rest of the gameplay it's fun, you should at least play it on easy and experience this grandpa of a game.

145062768.review:
Hands down a must play. Easily one of the finest games ever made.

That might sound like hyperbole, but I assure you that everything comes close to making a perfect game.

You don't need to be a Batman fanatic to enjoy this, it'll show you all that you need to understand Batman, his allies and his enemies. The characterization on display is flawless with what it works with. Further, it does it without stopping the game and doing a lore dump on you. The people and their reactions to each other tells you everything.

The combat is the right amount of hectic. The different varieties of enemy have a good amount of variety while still being a reasonable challenge. Rifles, fists, stun batons...lunatics, maximum security inmates, hulking mutants, mutant plants...it all sounds like it should fall apart under its weight, but the game keeps things varied, interesting and, most importantly, doable. Beautiful...

Arkham Asylum might just be the best Metroidvania, too. The map isn't ridiculously huge, but it seems vast and imposing enough when you start. The story masterfully takes you through different locations and, as you get more gear and hence "unlock" new areas, it'll take you back through many places. Further, it'll keep things fresh as the island you're on steadily falls further into chaos through the night.

It isn't perfect or flawless, nothing is, but Arkham Asylum is must-play gaming. Nothing less. Any clunk or frustration is mitigated by a forgiving checkpoint system and fun gameplay, glued together with an interesting and engaging story.

It's an absolute gem in my Steam library and I believe it can be for your collection as well.

145007330.review:
A Masterpiece of Darkness: Review of "Batman: Arkham Asylum GOTY Edition"

Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5)

"Batman: Arkham Asylum GOTY Edition" stands as a triumphant testament to what superhero games can achieve when the right elements come together. Developed by Rocksteady Studios, this immersive action-adventure game delivers an unforgettable experience that showcases the depths of Batman's psyche, unravels the sinister world of Arkham Asylum, and sets a new standard for superhero video games.

From the moment you step onto the rain-soaked grounds of Arkham Asylum, you're enveloped in an atmosphere of impending danger and mystery. The game's moody and visually stunning environments create a perfect backdrop for Batman's dark and complex story. The detail in character designs, architecture, and atmospheric effects demonstrates the developer's dedication to capturing the essence of the Batman universe.

Gameplay is a harmonious blend of fluid combat, intricate detective work, and stealth mechanics. The Freeflow Combat System enables players to unleash a flurry of strikes, counters, and combos in a balletic dance of combat that makes players feel every bit the Dark Knight. The Detective Mode, a signature feature of the series, adds a layer of strategic thinking as you analyze environments, uncover secrets, and piece together the puzzle of Arkham's mysteries.

The storytelling is a tour de force, embracing Batman's psychology and the rogues' gallery that surrounds him. Mark Hamill's legendary portrayal of the Joker is a standout, delivering a performance that solidifies his place as one of the definitive Joker voices. The narrative unfolds with a cinematic grace, revealing layers of the characters' motivations and conflicts that culminate in a gripping showdown.

The "Game of the Year" edition bundles in all the additional content, including Challenge Maps that test your combat and stealth skills, as well as the gripping "Joker's Carnival" expansion. This extends the game's replayability, giving players more ways to dive back into the world of Arkham Asylum.

The game isn't without minor flaws, such as occasional camera hiccups during combat and certain repetitive enemy encounters. However, these minor quibbles hardly detract from the overall excellence of the game.

The attention to detail extends beyond visuals to audio. The soundtrack contributes to the immersion, adapting to the pacing of the gameplay, and intensifying during action-packed moments or quiet investigations. The ambient sounds and voice acting add layers of authenticity to the characters and environments.

In conclusion, "Batman: Arkham Asylum GOTY Edition" is an undisputed masterpiece that redefined superhero gaming. Its gripping narrative, dynamic gameplay, and meticulous attention to detail combine to create an experience that both fans of Batman and enthusiasts of action-adventure games will savor. Rocksteady Studios' remarkable achievement here set a high bar for the entire genre, and even years after its initial release, it remains an essential cornerstone in the pantheon of video game history.

144874746.review:
This game is the godfather of basically every brawler in the last 14ish years and there is a good reason. I start the review this way because this is the most important thing to remember when you're playing this game. This game started the entire "counter-punch" system of combat that games to this day still use. And it feels almost as good in this game as it does in any of the games that copy it's design, even games made almost a decade and a half later.

There's a ton of great things to say here about the game. The story is a classic Batman romp. The graphics are great for the time. The voice acting, especially by Hamill and Conroy (RIP), is beyond amazing. And the music is just timeless. There's even a million and one collectables to collect if that's your thing.

But the biggest thing this game gets right is none of that. It's that this game makes you FEEL like Batman. You're big, your punches have weight. You are a complete badass. You can sneak and be stealthy terror. You can deduce (Detective Vision is yet another way this game shaped the industry, for the worse IMO, but still). You have an array of useful gadgets. But eventually you'll HAVE to punch. And when you punch, you feel the power behind those fists.

And that's truly this game's biggest strength. Which makes it the biggest weakness from a modern perspective as well. This combat has been done better since. Of course it has. Companies have had almost 14 years to perfect it. But that should in no way diminish this game or what it accomplished and in no way means you shouldn't still play this classic.

Recommended
